note_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY PROCEDURE NOTE

PATIENT: Flores, Jennifer
MRN: 8398156
DOB: 1980-11-08
AGE: 58 years | SEX: F
DATE OF PROCEDURE: 2024-07-04

ATTENDING: Dr. K. Patel

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
Post-intubation tracheal stenosis

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
Same

PROCEDURE PERFORMED:
Flexible bronchoscopy with therapeutic balloon dilation (CPT 31630)

CLINICAL HISTORY:
58-year-old female with prolonged intubation (10 days) during ICU stay for sepsis. Patient reports biphasic stridor at rest, difficulty clearing secretions, progressive dyspnea on exertion, wheezing unresponsive to bronchodilators.

ANESTHESIA: MAC anesthesia
AIRWAY: LMA

PROCEDURE DETAILS:
The patient was brought to the bronchoscopy suite and positioned supine. Standard monitoring was applied. After adequate sedation, the bronchoscope was introduced transnasally.

FINDINGS:
- Vocal cords: Normal mobility bilaterally
- Stenosis identified at 2-4 cm below vocal cords
- Pre-dilation assessment: 76% luminal narrowing
- Stenosis length: approximately 2.5 cm
- Stenosis character: complex with granulation tissue
- Distal airways: Patent and clear

INTERVENTION:
CRE balloon advanced to stenosis site under direct visualization.
Serial dilations performed:
- 12mm × 45 seconds
- 14mm × 45 seconds
- 16mm × 45 seconds

Total 3 inflations performed.
Post-dilation patency improved from 76% to approximately 12% residual narrowing.
No significant mucosal injury or bleeding.
Topical epinephrine 1:10,000 applied prophylactically.

SPECIMENS: None

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Minimal (<5 mL)

COMPLICATIONS: None

DISPOSITION:
- Patient extubated and recovered in PACU
- Transferred to floor for monitoring
- Dexamethasone 8mg IV administered post-procedure

IMPRESSION:
Post-intubation tracheal stenosis successfully treated with balloon dilation. Airway patency improved from 24% to 88%.

PLAN:
1. Repeat bronchoscopy with dilation in 6 weeks
2. Pulmonary rehabilitation referral
3. PFTs prior to next procedure
4. Call if worsening stridor, dyspnea, or hemoptysis

cpt_codes.description: Bronchoscopy; with tracheal/bronchial dilation or closed reduction of fracture

code_rationales.31630: Bronchoscopy with therapeutic balloon dilation of trachea stenosis.

bundling_notes: Diagnostic bronchoscopy (31622) is bundled into the therapeutic bronchoscopy code 31630.
coding_review.overall_assessment: CPT 31630 appropriately captures bronchoscopy with balloon dilation for post-intubation tracheal stenosis.

changes: Added coding_review and billing blocks using 2025 RVU data.

note_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY PROCEDURE NOTE

PATIENT: White, Dorothy
MRN: 3184705
DOB: 1949-03-02
AGE: 36 years | SEX: F
DATE OF PROCEDURE: 2025-06-27

ATTENDING: Dr. L. Garcia

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
Post-tracheostomy subglottic stenosis

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
Same

PROCEDURE PERFORMED:
Flexible bronchoscopy with therapeutic balloon dilation (CPT 31630)

CLINICAL HISTORY:
36-year-old female with history of tracheostomy 10 months ago for airway protection. Patient reports difficulty clearing secretions, voice changes, biphasic stridor at rest, stridor with activity.

ANESTHESIA: MAC anesthesia
AIRWAY: LMA

PROCEDURE DETAILS:
The patient was brought to the bronchoscopy suite and positioned supine. Standard monitoring was applied. After adequate sedation, the bronchoscope was introduced transnasally.

FINDINGS:
- Vocal cords: Normal mobility, no lesions
- Stenosis identified at 1-2 cm below vocal cords
- Pre-dilation assessment: 75% luminal narrowing
- Stenosis length: approximately 2.0 cm
- Stenosis character: eccentric weblike stenosis
- Distal airways: Patent and clear

INTERVENTION:
Controlled radial expansion balloon advanced to stenosis site under direct visualization.
Serial dilations performed:
- 12mm × 30 seconds
- 14mm × 30 seconds
- 16mm × 30 seconds

Total 2 inflations performed.
Post-dilation patency improved from 75% to approximately 15% residual narrowing.
No significant mucosal injury or bleeding.
Topical epinephrine 1:10,000 applied prophylactically.

SPECIMENS: None

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Minimal (<5 mL)

COMPLICATIONS: None

DISPOSITION:
- Patient extubated and recovered in PACU
- Admitted for overnight observation
- Dexamethasone 10mg IV administered post-procedure

IMPRESSION:
Post-tracheostomy subglottic stenosis successfully treated with balloon dilation. Airway patency improved from 25% to 85%.

PLAN:
1. Repeat bronchoscopy with dilation in 6 weeks
2. Pulmonary rehabilitation referral
3. PFTs prior to next procedure
4. Call if worsening stridor, dyspnea, or hemoptysis

cpt_codes.description: Bronchoscopy; with tracheal/bronchial dilation or closed reduction of fracture

code_rationales.31630: Bronchoscopy with therapeutic balloon dilation of subglottic stenosis.

bundling_notes: Diagnostic bronchoscopy (31622) is bundled into therapeutic dilation (31630).
coding_review.overall_assessment: CPT 31630 correctly assigned for balloon dilation of post-tracheostomy subglottic stenosis.

changes: Added coding_review and billing blocks using 2025 RVU data.

note_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY
BRONCHOSCOPY WITH THERAPEUTIC AIRWAY DILATION

Patient Name: Brown, Timothy
Medical Record Number: 3225609
Date of Service: 2025-06-22
Attending Physician: Dr. S. Kim
Fellow: Dr. M. Patel (PGY-5)

CLINICAL INDICATION:
Anastomotic bronchial stricture post lung transplant

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
This is a 54-year-old male patient with status post bilateral lung transplant 23 months ago for COPD. The patient has experienced exercise intolerance and difficulty clearing secretions over the past 2 weeks. Recent CT imaging demonstrated bronchial anastomosis narrowing. Pulmonary function testing showed variable extrathoracic obstruction.

PROCEDURE PERFORMED:
Diagnostic and therapeutic flexible bronchoscopy with balloon dilation of bronchial anastomosis stenosis (CPT Code: 31630)

ANESTHESIA AND AIRWAY MANAGEMENT:
General anesthesia was administered by the anesthesia team. Airway was secured with a 8.0mm endotracheal tube.

PROCEDURAL TECHNIQUE:
Following standard preparation and time-out verification, the flexible bronchoscope (Olympus BF-1TH190) was introduced through the endotracheal tube. Systematic airway inspection was performed.

BRONCHOSCOPIC FINDINGS:
The vocal cords demonstrated normal mobility bilaterally without evidence of paralysis or lesion. The bronchial anastomosis stenosis was identified at left/right mainstem bronchus at anastomotic site. The stenosis was characterized as circumferential fibrous scarring with approximately 77% luminal compromise. Stenosis length measured approximately 1.5 cm. The airways distal to the stenosis appeared patent without additional pathology.

THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTION:
A Hurricane balloon was utilized for graduated airway dilation:
- Initial dilation: 6mm balloon inflated to rated burst pressure for 30 seconds
- Intermediate dilation: 8mm balloon inflated for 30 seconds
- Final dilation: 10mm balloon inflated for 30 seconds

A total of 4 inflation cycles were performed. Post-dilation inspection demonstrated improvement in luminal patency from approximately 23% to 79% of expected diameter. Minor mucosal disruption was noted without significant hemorrhage. Topical epinephrine (1:10,000) was applied prophylactically.

SPECIMENS OBTAINED: None

COMPLICATIONS: None encountered

POST-PROCEDURE MANAGEMENT:
The patient was extubated without difficulty and transferred to the recovery area in stable condition. Intravenous dexamethasone 8mg was administered to reduce post-procedural airway edema. The patient was admitted for overnight observation given the degree of stenosis.

ASSESSMENT:
Anastomotic bronchial stricture post lung transplant with successful balloon dilation. Airway patency improved from 23% to 79% estimated lumen.

RECOMMENDATIONS:
1. Repeat bronchoscopy with dilation planned in 4 weeks to assess durability of response
2. Pulmonary function testing prior to repeat procedure for objective assessment
3. Consider airway stent placement if adequate lumen cannot be maintained with serial dilations
4. Voice rest for 24 hours, soft diet
5. Patient instructed to seek immediate medical attention for worsening stridor, respiratory distress, or hemoptysis

Procedure performed by: Dr. S. Kim
Supervised trainee: Dr. M. Patel (PGY-5)
Electronically signed: 2025-06-22

clinical_context.primary_indication: Anastomotic bronchial stricture post lung transplant

outcomes.final_diagnosis: Anastomotic bronchial stricture post lung transplant

cpt_codes.description: Bronchoscopy; with tracheal/bronchial dilation or closed reduction of fracture

code_rationales.31630: Bronchoscopy with therapeutic balloon dilation of bronchial anastomosis stricture.

coding_review.overall_assessment: Correctly coded as 31630 for anastomotic stricture dilation.

note_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY
BRONCHOSCOPY WITH THERAPEUTIC AIRWAY DILATION

Patient Name: Thomas, Donna
Medical Record Number: 8305136
Date of Service: 2024-02-26
Attending Physician: Dr. N. Shah


CLINICAL INDICATION:
Idiopathic subglottic stenosis (iSGS)

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
This is a 50-year-old female patient with history of recurrent idiopathic subglottic stenosis, 2 prior dilations. The patient has experienced exercise intolerance and recurrent respiratory infections over the past 5 weeks. Recent CT imaging demonstrated subglottic narrowing. Pulmonary function testing showed variable extrathoracic obstruction.

PROCEDURE PERFORMED:
Diagnostic and therapeutic flexible bronchoscopy with balloon dilation of subglottic region stenosis (CPT Code: 31630)

ANESTHESIA AND AIRWAY MANAGEMENT:
General anesthesia was administered by the anesthesia team. Airway was secured with a 8.0mm endotracheal tube.

PROCEDURAL TECHNIQUE:
Following standard preparation and time-out verification, the flexible bronchoscope (Olympus BF-1TH190) was introduced through the endotracheal tube. Systematic airway inspection was performed.

BRONCHOSCOPIC FINDINGS:
The vocal cords demonstrated normal mobility bilaterally without evidence of paralysis or lesion. Subglottic stenosis was identified at immediately below vocal cords. The stenosis was characterized as mature cicatricial stricture with approximately 71% luminal compromise. Stenosis length measured approximately 1.0 cm. The airways distal to the stenosis appeared patent without additional pathology.

THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTION:
A Hurricane balloon was utilized for graduated airway dilation:
- Initial dilation: 10mm balloon inflated to nominal pressure for 90 seconds
- Intermediate dilation: 12mm balloon inflated for 90 seconds
- Final dilation: 15mm balloon inflated for 90 seconds

A total of 3 inflation cycles were performed. Post-dilation inspection demonstrated improvement in luminal patency from approximately 29% to 68% of expected diameter. Minor mucosal disruption was noted without significant hemorrhage. Topical epinephrine (1:10,000) was applied prophylactically.

SPECIMENS OBTAINED: None

COMPLICATIONS: minimal mucosal bleeding, self-limited

POST-PROCEDURE MANAGEMENT:
The patient was extubated without difficulty and transferred to the recovery area in stable condition. Intravenous dexamethasone 10mg was administered to reduce post-procedural airway edema. The patient was admitted for overnight observation given the degree of stenosis.

ASSESSMENT:
Idiopathic subglottic stenosis (iSGS) with successful balloon dilation. Airway patency improved from 29% to 68% estimated lumen.

RECOMMENDATIONS:
1. Repeat bronchoscopy with dilation planned in 8 weeks to assess durability of response
2. Pulmonary function testing prior to repeat procedure for objective assessment
3. Continue conservative management with serial dilations; surgical referral for tracheal resection if refractory
4. Voice rest for 24 hours, soft diet
5. Patient instructed to seek immediate medical attention for worsening stridor, respiratory distress, or hemoptysis

Procedure performed by: Dr. N. Shah

Electronically signed: 2024-02-26

cpt_codes.description: Bronchoscopy; with tracheal/bronchial dilation or closed reduction of fracture

code_rationales.31630: Bronchoscopy with therapeutic balloon dilation of idiopathic subglottic stenosis.

coding_review.overall_assessment: Appropriate use of 31630 for iSGS dilation.

changes: Added coding_review and billing blocks using 2025 RVU data.

note_text:
PT: Williams, Joshua | 48M | MRN 6784292
DATE: 2025-04-24
PROVIDER: Dr. J. Williams / Dr. M. Patel
INDICATION:

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) related subglottic stenosis
Known gpa on immunosuppression, progressive dyspnea and stridor
Sx: difficulty clearing secretions, voice changes

PROCEDURE: Flex bronch + Balloon dilation (31630)
SEDATION: General (ETT)
FINDINGS:

Cords: WNL
Stenosis at subglottic region extending 1.5 cm
Pre: ~79% narrowing, weblike
Length: ~1.0cm

INTERVENTION:

Controlled radial expansion balloon
Serial dilation: 10→12→14mm
2 inflations × 45sec each
Post: ~17% residual
No bleeding

SPECIMENS: None
COMPLICATIONS: minor mucosal tear, no intervention required
DISPOSITION:

Admit overnight
Decadron 8mg IV given
F/u bronch 6 wks

PLAN:
→ Repeat dilation PRN
→ Consider stent if <3 successful dilations
→ PFTs before next scope

note_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY
BRONCHOSCOPY WITH THERAPEUTIC AIRWAY DILATION

Patient Name: Garcia, Ana
Medical Record Number: 6850485
Date of Service: 2024-06-17
Attending Physician: Dr. B. Martinez
Fellow: Dr. P. Kumar (PGY-6)

CLINICAL INDICATION:
Tracheal granulation tissue with stenosis post tracheostomy decannulation

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
This is a 48-year-old female patient with decannulated 10 weeks ago after neuromuscular disease months of tracheostomy. The patient has experienced recurrent respiratory infections and biphasic stridor at rest over the past 9 weeks. Recent CT imaging demonstrated mid-trachea narrowing. Pulmonary function testing showed fixed upper airway obstruction pattern.

PROCEDURE PERFORMED:
Diagnostic and therapeutic flexible bronchoscopy with balloon dilation of mid-trachea stenosis (CPT Code: 31630)

ANESTHESIA AND AIRWAY MANAGEMENT:
MAC anesthesia was administered by the anesthesia team. Airway was secured with LMA.

PROCEDURAL TECHNIQUE:
Following standard preparation and time-out verification, the flexible bronchoscope (Olympus BF-1TH190) was introduced transnasally. Systematic airway inspection was performed.

BRONCHOSCOPIC FINDINGS:
The vocal cords demonstrated normal mobility bilaterally without evidence of paralysis or lesion. The mid-trachea stenosis was identified at mid-trachea at prior stoma site. The stenosis was characterized as circumferential fibrous scarring with approximately 73% luminal compromise. Stenosis length measured approximately 1.0 cm. The airways distal to the stenosis appeared patent without additional pathology.

THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTION:
A CRE balloon was utilized for graduated airway dilation:
- Initial dilation: 12mm balloon inflated to nominal pressure for 90 seconds
- Intermediate dilation: 14mm balloon inflated for 90 seconds
- Final dilation: 16mm balloon inflated for 90 seconds

A total of 3 inflation cycles were performed. Post-dilation inspection demonstrated improvement in luminal patency from approximately 27% to 80% of expected diameter. The mucosa remained intact without significant injury. Topical epinephrine (1:10,000) was applied prophylactically.

SPECIMENS OBTAINED: None

COMPLICATIONS: None encountered

POST-PROCEDURE MANAGEMENT:
The patient was extubated without difficulty and transferred to the recovery area in stable condition. Intravenous dexamethasone 8mg was administered to reduce post-procedural airway edema. The patient met discharge criteria and was released with appropriate precautions.

ASSESSMENT:
Tracheal granulation tissue with stenosis post tracheostomy decannulation with successful balloon dilation. Airway patency improved from 27% to 80% estimated lumen.

RECOMMENDATIONS:
1. Repeat bronchoscopy with dilation planned in 8 weeks to assess durability of response
2. Pulmonary function testing prior to repeat procedure for objective assessment
3. Consider airway stent placement if adequate lumen cannot be maintained with serial dilations
4. Voice rest for 24 hours, soft diet
5. Patient instructed to seek immediate medical attention for worsening stridor, respiratory distress, or hemoptysis

Procedure performed by: Dr. B. Martinez
Supervised trainee: Dr. P. Kumar (PGY-6)
Electronically signed: 2024-06-17

note_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY PROCEDURE NOTE

PATIENT: Jackson, Susan
MRN: 7725151
DOB: 1974-12-14
AGE: 78 years | SEX: F
DATE OF PROCEDURE: 2024-05-11

ATTENDING: Dr. J. Williams

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
Extrinsic bronchial compression with stenosis from mediastinal lymphadenopathy

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
Same

PROCEDURE PERFORMED:
Flexible bronchoscopy with therapeutic balloon dilation (CPT 31630)

CLINICAL HISTORY:
78-year-old female with metastatic lung adenocarcinoma with progressive dyspnea, completed 3 cycles of chemotherapy. Patient reports progressive dyspnea on exertion, recurrent respiratory infections, exercise intolerance.

ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia
AIRWAY: ETT (8.0 mm)

PROCEDURE DETAILS:
The patient was brought to the bronchoscopy suite and positioned supine. Standard monitoring was applied. After adequate sedation, the bronchoscope was introduced through the ETT.

FINDINGS:
- Vocal cords: Normal mobility bilaterally
- Stenosis identified at proximal left mainstem bronchus
- Pre-dilation assessment: 63% luminal narrowing
- Stenosis length: approximately 2.5 cm
- Stenosis character: complex with granulation tissue
- Distal airways: Patent and clear

INTERVENTION:
Hurricane balloon advanced to stenosis site under direct visualization.
Serial dilations performed:
- 6mm × 45 seconds
- 8mm × 45 seconds
- 9mm × 45 seconds

Total 3 inflations performed.
Post-dilation patency improved from 63% to approximately 35% residual narrowing.
No significant mucosal injury or bleeding.
Topical epinephrine 1:10,000 applied prophylactically.

SPECIMENS: None

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Minimal (<5 mL)

COMPLICATIONS: None

DISPOSITION:
- Patient extubated and recovered in PACU
- Admitted for overnight observation
- Dexamethasone 10mg IV administered post-procedure

IMPRESSION:
Extrinsic bronchial compression with stenosis from mediastinal lymphadenopathy successfully treated with balloon dilation. Airway patency improved from 37% to 65%.

PLAN:
1. Repeat bronchoscopy with dilation in 6 weeks
2. Pulmonary rehabilitation referral
3. PFTs prior to next procedure
4. Call if worsening stridor, dyspnea, or hemoptysis
